metadata.scope: External passive security audit of Brand Collective's 20 Shopify storefronts and integrations

findings.title: Omneo Loyalty Platform â€” PII Enumeration via /api/auth/availability (CRITICAL)
findings.detail: The /api/auth/availability endpoint on Omneo loyalty portals returns full PII (full name, UUID, loyalty card number) for any email address. No authentication required. Confirmed exploitable on SNS (test@test.com â†’ 'Jayden Potts', UUID 9a6f4458-2eab-44e3-b26f-0351007cdec9, loyalty card L142697892) and Review (my.review-australia.com). This is a platform-level issue affecting ALL brands using Omneo portals. Vendor claimed patch was applied â€” verified STILL FULLY EXPLOITABLE on Feb 16.
findings.recommendation: ESCALATE IMMEDIATELY. Omneo's claimed patch did not fix this vulnerability. Consider: (1) Demand Omneo disable these endpoints immediately, (2) Block public access to /api/auth/* endpoints via WAF/proxy, (3) Engage legal counsel re: data breach notification obligations under Privacy Act, (4) Consider OAIC notification if customer PII has been accessed by unauthorized parties.
findings.status: Reported Feb 10 â€” still unpatched as of Feb 16 retest

retestHistory.event: Initially discovered â€” PII enumeration via /api/auth/availability, /api/auth/sms, /api/auth/magic, wildcard CORS, missing security headers
Re-audited â€” 0/8 findings patched. All endpoints still fully exploitable

Retested. /api/auth/magic now returns 404 â€” vendor claimed fix for this endpoint VERIFIED FIXED. However, all PII enumeration endpoints (/api/auth/availability, /api/auth, /api/auth/sms) remain fully exploitable and unpatched. NEW endpoint /api/auth found returning even MORE data (join date). Critical PII exposure remains unaddressed.

findings.title: Omneo Loyalty Platform â€” PII Enumeration via /api/auth (NEW â€” WORSE)
findings.detail: NEW FINDING (Feb 16): The /api/auth POST endpoint returns MORE data than /api/auth/availability: UUID, email, loyalty card number, AND join date. No authentication required. SNS: returns id, email, identity (loyalty card), joined_at ('2021-05-20 00:00:00'). Review: returns same fields, loyalty card L181241163, joined '2020-01-09 00:00:00'. This endpoint was not previously documented and represents an escalation â€” more PII is exposed than the original finding.
findings.recommendation: Same as F001 â€” this endpoint must be blocked or require authentication immediately. The join date field adds additional PII exposure beyond the original finding.
findings.status: Reported Feb 10 â€” still unpatched as of Feb 16 retest

findings.title: Omneo Loyalty Platform â€” SMS Phone Number Enumeration via /api/auth/sms
findings.detail: The /api/auth/sms endpoint returns loyalty card numbers for any phone number. No authentication required. Confirmed: +61400000000 â†’ identity: 'L144125172'. Allows mass enumeration of customer loyalty accounts by phone number.
findings.recommendation: Block or rate-limit /api/auth/sms endpoint. Require authentication before returning any customer data.
findings.status: Reported Feb 10 â€” still unpatched as of Feb 16 retest

findings.title: Omneo Loyalty Platform â€” Wildcard CORS on All API Endpoints
findings.detail: All Omneo portal API endpoints return Access-Control-Allow-Origin: * header. This means ANY website on the internet can make cross-origin requests to these endpoints and read the responses. Combined with the PII enumeration vulnerabilities (F001, F001a, F001b), any malicious website can silently harvest customer data from Omneo portals.
findings.recommendation: Omneo must restrict CORS to only allow requests from legitimate portal domains. Wildcard CORS on endpoints returning PII is a critical misconfiguration.
findings.status: Reported Feb 10 â€” still unpatched as of Feb 16 retest

findings.title: Omneo Loyalty Portal â€” Missing Security Headers
findings.detail: Omneo loyalty portals are missing critical security headers: no Content-Security-Policy, no X-Frame-Options, no HSTS. Portals expose x-powered-by: Next.js and server: Google Frontend headers, revealing technology stack. These missing headers compound the other vulnerabilities.
findings.recommendation: Omneo must implement CSP, X-Frame-Options, HSTS, and remove technology disclosure headers.
findings.status: Reported Feb 10 â€” still unpatched as of Feb 16 retest

findings.title: Omneo Loyalty Platform â€” Magic Link Token Exposure (Possibly Partially Fixed)
findings.detail: The /api/auth/magic endpoint previously allowed magic link token generation/exposure. As of Feb 16 retest, this endpoint now returns 404 on both SNS and Review portals. Omneo claimed they fixed this specific issue â€” confirmed fixed. However, all PII enumeration endpoints (/api/auth/availability, /api/auth, /api/auth/sms) remain fully exploitable and were not part of this fix.
findings.recommendation: No further action on this specific endpoint. Focus remediation efforts on the critical PII enumeration endpoints (F001, F001a, F001b) and wildcard CORS (F001c) which remain unpatched.
findings.status: Vendor claimed fix â€” VERIFIED FIXED (endpoint returns 404)

findings.title: Shopify Product API Publicly Accessible â€” All 20 Stores
findings.detail: The /products.json, /collections.json, and /cart.json endpoints are publicly accessible (HTTP 200) on all 20 stores. This exposes product catalog data including: product IDs, titles, descriptions (body_html), SKUs, pricing, compare-at prices, variant details, tags, vendor info, timestamps, and image URLs. While this is default Shopify behavior, the SKU format (e.g., RBK149976_9NV_3_5) reveals internal inventory coding conventions. Combined with /collections.json exposing collection structure and product counts, this provides competitors with complete catalog intelligence.
findings.recommendation: Implement Shopify's Storefront API access scoping to restrict /products.json access. Consider using the Admin API with authentication for any legitimate integrations that need this data. At minimum, review what sensitive data (internal SKU formats, vendor names, tags) is exposed and sanitize product metadata.

findings.title: DMARC Policy Set to 'none' on 18 of 19 Domains
findings.detail: 18 out of 19 auditable domains have DMARC set to p=none, meaning email spoofing/phishing using these domains will not be rejected or quarantined. All DMARC reports go to dmarc@brandcollective.com.au. Only Canada Goose has p=reject (using DMARC Analyzer). With p=none, attackers can send phishing emails appearing to come from any Brand Collective domain and they will be delivered to recipients.
findings.recommendation: Migrate all domains from p=none to p=quarantine, then to p=reject. Use the existing DMARC reporting (dmarc@brandcollective.com.au) to monitor for legitimate email sources that might break. Consider adopting DMARC Analyzer (already used by Canada Goose) across all domains for visibility. Priority: High-value brands first (Review, Reebok, Superdry, Champion).

findings.title: Weak Content Security Policy â€” All 20 Stores
findings.detail: All stores use the same minimal Shopify-default CSP: 'block-all-mixed-content; frame-ancestors none; upgrade-insecure-requests'. This CSP does NOT restrict script-src, style-src, img-src, connect-src, or font-src directives. Any injected script from any origin will execute. This is particularly concerning given the number of third-party scripts loaded (Klaviyo, Gorgias, Intelligems, various tracking pixels).
findings.recommendation: Implement a comprehensive CSP with explicit script-src, style-src, img-src, connect-src, and font-src directives whitelisting only required domains. Start in report-only mode (Content-Security-Policy-Report-Only) to identify breakage before enforcing. Key domains to whitelist: cdn.shopify.com, static.klaviyo.com, config.gorgias.chat, cdn.intelligems.io, and specific analytics/pixel domains.

findings.title: Missing Permissions-Policy Header â€” All 20 Stores
findings.detail: No store returns a Permissions-Policy (formerly Feature-Policy) header. This means the browser's default permissions apply, potentially allowing third-party iframes/scripts to access sensitive APIs like camera, microphone, geolocation, payment, etc.
findings.recommendation: Add Permissions-Policy header restricting sensitive features: Permissions-Policy: camera=(), microphone=(), geolocation=(), payment=(self), usb=(), interest-cohort=(). This can be set at the Shopify theme level or via Cloudflare workers/transform rules.

findings.title: Missing Referrer-Policy Header â€” All 20 Stores
findings.detail: No store sets a Referrer-Policy header. Browser default behavior may leak full URLs (including query parameters with potential PII like search queries, UTM parameters, customer tokens) to third-party services when users click external links or load third-party resources.
findings.recommendation: Add Referrer-Policy: strict-origin-when-cross-origin header to all stores. This sends only the origin (not full URL) to cross-origin requests while maintaining full referrer for same-origin requests.

findings.title: Non-Essential Cookies Missing Secure and HttpOnly Flags
findings.detail: The 'localization' and 'cart_currency' cookies are set without Secure or HttpOnly flags on all stores. Additionally, _shopify_y and _shopify_s tracking cookies lack HttpOnly flag. While these don't contain authentication data, the missing Secure flag means they could be sent over HTTP if a user accidentally visits an HTTP URL (before HSTS redirect).
findings.recommendation: Configure Shopify cookie settings to add Secure flag to all cookies. For cookies that don't need JavaScript access (localization, cart_currency), add HttpOnly flag. This is partially a Shopify platform limitation but can be supplemented with Cloudflare transform rules.

findings.title: Shopify Store IDs and Internal Naming Exposed in Headers
findings.detail: All stores expose x-shopid header with the Shopify store ID, 'powered-by: Shopify' header, and detailed server-timing headers revealing: internal request IDs, theme IDs, data center locations (gcp-australia-southeast2), page types, served-by node identifiers, compression levels, and session IDs. The .myshopify.com subdomain naming convention also reveals internal naming (e.g., 'blackpepper-prod', 'superdry-prod', '82dccf-2', 'f7c61c') indicating production environments and some using opaque Shopify-generated names.
findings.recommendation: While most of this is Shopify platform behavior and cannot be fully suppressed, consider: (1) Using Cloudflare to strip x-shopid and server-timing headers from responses, (2) Review .myshopify.com subdomain names for any that reveal sensitive info, (3) The 'powered-by: Shopify' header is informational and low-risk but could be stripped.

findings.title: Third-Party Scripts Loaded Without SRI Hashes
findings.detail: While Shopify CDN scripts use SRI hashes (2 integrity attributes found on sampled pages), third-party scripts from Klaviyo (static.klaviyo.com), Gorgias (config.gorgias.chat), Intelligems (cdn.intelligems.io), and others are loaded without Subresource Integrity (SRI) hashes. If any of these CDNs are compromised, malicious code would execute on all Brand Collective stores.
findings.recommendation: Add integrity attributes with SHA-384/SHA-512 hashes to all third-party script tags where the script content is static. For dynamically loaded scripts (Klaviyo, Gorgias loaders), implement a strict CSP as a compensating control. Monitor third-party script changes using tools like PerimeterX or Jscrambler.

findings.title: SPF Records Include Stale/Legacy Services
findings.detail: Multiple domains include SPF entries for services that may no longer be in use: spf.hes.trendmicro.com (legacy email security), spf.mandrillapp.com (Mailchimp Transactional), _spf.bigcommerce.com (previous platform), servers.mcsv.net (Mailchimp), mail.zendesk.com, authsmtp.com (Superdry), sendgrid.net (Shoes & Sox). Including unused SPF entries increases the attack surface for email spoofing. Superdry's SPF also has a duplicate ip4:202.72.34.128/28 entry and uses ~all (softfail) instead of -all (hardfail).
findings.recommendation: Audit all SPF includes against actively used email services. Remove any stale entries (BigCommerce, Mandrill if not in use, TrendMicro legacy). Fix Superdry's duplicate IP range and upgrade from ~all to -all. Consolidate SPF records to stay under the 10 DNS lookup limit. Consider using SPF flattening to reduce lookups.

findings.title: Harrison Domain â€” DNS Misconfiguration
findings.detail: The Harrison brand has DNS issues: harrisonsonline.com.au redirects via WordPress to harrison.com.au, which then redirects to harrison-shoes.com.au. This multi-hop redirect chain suggests legacy domain management. No SPF, DMARC, or MX records found for harrison-shoes.com.au during the audit. The WordPress intermediate redirect also suggests a legacy server that may need attention.
findings.recommendation: Consolidate Harrison domains to a single canonical domain (harrison-shoes.com.au). Remove the WordPress redirect server and configure direct DNS redirects. Set up proper SPF, DMARC, and DKIM records for harrison-shoes.com.au. Ensure the old domains (harrisonsonline.com.au, harrison.com.au) properly redirect without exposing WordPress.

findings.title: HSTS Max-Age Below Recommended Value
findings.detail: All stores set Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=7889238 (approximately 91 days). The recommended minimum is 31536000 (1 year) for HSTS preload eligibility. None of the stores include 'includeSubDomains' or 'preload' directives, meaning they are not eligible for browser HSTS preload lists.
findings.recommendation: Increase HSTS max-age to 31536000 (1 year) and add includeSubDomains and preload directives. Submit all domains to the HSTS preload list at hstspreload.org. This is a Shopify platform default â€” file a request with Shopify or implement via Cloudflare response header transforms.

findings.title: Localization and Cart Cookies Set Without SameSite=Strict
findings.detail: The 'localization' and 'cart_currency' cookies are set without any SameSite attribute (defaults to Lax in modern browsers). Shopify tracking cookies use SameSite=Lax. None use SameSite=Strict. While Lax provides basic CSRF protection, Strict would provide stronger protection for checkout flows.
findings.recommendation: Where possible, set SameSite=Strict on non-essential cookies. The _shopify_essential cookie correctly uses SameSite=Lax which is appropriate for authentication cookies that need to work with top-level navigations.

findings.title: Deprecated X-XSS-Protection Header Present
findings.detail: All stores return X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block. This header is deprecated and can actually introduce vulnerabilities in older browsers. Modern browsers have removed their XSS auditor functionality.
findings.recommendation: Remove X-XSS-Protection header and rely on CSP for XSS protection instead. If removal isn't possible (Shopify default), set to X-XSS-Protection: 0 to disable the potentially problematic XSS auditor.

findings.title: All Stores Using Cloudflare + Shopify CDN
findings.detail: All 20 stores are fronted by Cloudflare (server: cloudflare) with cf-cache-status: DYNAMIC. Backend is Shopify's multi-region infrastructure (gcp-australia-southeast2 primary, gcp-asia-southeast1 secondary). All .myshopify.com domains correctly redirect (301) to custom domains. HTTP/2 and HTTP/3 (h3) are enabled across all stores.
findings.recommendation: No action required. This is a strong infrastructure setup. Consider enabling Cloudflare's additional security features (Bot Management, WAF rules) if not already active.

findings.title: Shopify .myshopify.com Domains Properly Redirect
findings.detail: All 20 .myshopify.com domains correctly return 301 redirects to their custom domains. No stores are directly accessible via .myshopify.com URLs. Note: Some myshopify subdomain names reveal environment info (e.g., '-prod' suffix, opaque IDs like '82dccf-2' and 'f7c61c').
findings.recommendation: No immediate action. The prod suffix naming convention is common and low-risk. Consider if obfuscated names (82dccf-2, f7c61c) for Julius Marlow and Clarks are intentional for additional security through obscurity.

findings.title: Strong Base Security Headers Present
findings.detail: All stores correctly implement: X-Frame-Options: DENY, X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff, X-Permitted-Cross-Domain-Policies: none, X-Download-Options: noopen, Content-Security-Policy frame-ancestors 'none' (consistent with X-Frame-Options), and upgrade-insecure-requests directive.
findings.recommendation: No action required. These are well-configured baseline headers.

integrations.name: Klaviyo
integrations.finding: Klaviyo JS loaded on multiple stores (e.g., company IDs W4U8xV for Reebok, ShN5VB for Champion, SP8jKd for Black Pepper). Company IDs are publicly exposed in script URLs. These IDs could potentially be used to probe Klaviyo API endpoints for list enumeration.

integrations.name: Gorgias
integrations.finding: Gorgias chat bundle loader is publicly accessible and exposes application keys (e.g., 01JSZWNGYNJS8J64J6FJGAREF3 for Champion, app ID 64965). The bundle-loader endpoint at config.gorgias.chat returns full JavaScript with API keys embedded. Could allow unauthorized chat widget instantiation.

integrations.name: Intelligems
integrations.finding: Intelligems A/B testing script (cdn.intelligems.io) loaded on Reebok and Black Pepper with store-specific bundle IDs (6ccd53f2c93f, e967ec415f3a). Scripts loaded without SRI. Intelligems has access to modify pricing and content for A/B tests.

integrations.name: Omneo
integrations.finding: CRITICAL: 4 critical findings remain unpatched. (1) /api/auth/availability returns full name, UUID, loyalty card for any email, (2) /api/auth returns UUID, email, loyalty card, AND join date â€” NEW and WORSE than original, (3) /api/auth/sms returns loyalty card for any phone number, (4) Wildcard CORS allows any website to exploit all endpoints. Magic link endpoint (/api/auth/magic) fixed by vendor (returns 404). All PII enumeration endpoints remain fully exploitable. Confirmed on my.shoesandsox.com.au and my.review-australia.com. Platform-level issue affects ALL brands using Omneo portals (25+ Australian retailers).

retestHistory.event: Magic link fix verified. All PII endpoints still unpatched. New worse endpoint (/api/auth) found.

integrations.name: Shopify Payments
integrations.finding: Standard Shopify Payments implementation detected. Portable wallets JS loaded. Payment processing handled by Shopify's PCI-DSS compliant infrastructure. No direct payment data exposure observed.

integrations.name: Google Analytics (GA4)
integrations.finding: GA4 implemented via Shopify's built-in integration and custom datalayer scripts (bc-datalayer.js). Standard implementation with no observable issues.

integrations.name: Facebook/Meta Pixel
integrations.finding: Standard Meta Pixel implementation via Shopify app. Pixel fires are handled through Shopify's web pixel extension framework.

integrations.name: Impact
integrations.finding: Impact affiliate tracking implemented. No exposed API endpoints detected.

integrations.name: Roseperl CDN
integrations.finding: cdn.roseperl.com returns 403 Access Denied on root (S3 bucket behind CloudFront). Directory listing is disabled. No data exposure detected from the CDN directly.

integrations.name: Preezie
integrations.finding: Preezie product recommendation widget loaded on Black Pepper (preeziecdn.azureedge.net). Script loaded without SRI hash.

integrations.name: Wishlist King
integrations.finding: Swish Wishlist King app detected on Reebok. Loaded via Shopify CDN extensions with standard implementation.

integrations.name: Flipbook
integrations.finding: Flipbook widget (flipbook.bestfreecdn.com) loaded on Black Pepper with shop ID exposed in URL parameter. Third-party CDN domain 'bestfreecdn.com' raises trust questions.

integrations.name: Zooomyapps Lookbook
integrations.finding: Lookbook script from zooomyapps.com loaded on Black Pepper. Unfamiliar third-party domain without SRI.

integrations.name: BC Cookie Banner
integrations.finding: Custom Brand Collective cookie banner (bc-cookiebanner.js) deployed via Shopify web pixel extension. Consistent implementation across stores.

integrations.name: 9GTB (Content)
integrations.finding: Script from content.9gtb.com/loader.js loaded on Champion. This domain and service are not immediately identifiable, raising supply chain risk questions.

integrations.name: Attentive
integrations.finding: Attentive SMS marketing integration detected via Shopify app framework. No directly exposed API endpoints found.

integrations.name: Afterpay/Zip Pay/PayPal
integrations.finding: Buy-now-pay-later providers implemented via standard Shopify integrations. Payment flows handled through Shopify's secure checkout. No direct API exposure.

integrations.name: Shop Pay
integrations.finding: Shop Pay/Shop app integration active across all stores (shop.app/checkouts/internal/preloads.js). Standard Shopify implementation.

thirdPartyScripts.note: App keys exposed in loader script
Has ability to modify pricing display
Unknown CDN provider, shop ID in URL
Unidentifiable service â€” potential supply chain risk

recommendations.action: ESCALATE: Omneo fixed magic link token issue only. 3 critical PII enumeration endpoints + wildcard CORS remain fully exploitable as of Feb 16 retest. New worse endpoint (/api/auth) discovered. Demand immediate remediation, consider WAF blocks, assess Privacy Act notification obligations.
Upgrade DMARC policy from p=none to p=quarantine then p=reject across all 18 domains
Implement comprehensive Content Security Policy with explicit source directives
Add Permissions-Policy and Referrer-Policy headers to all stores
Investigate and verify content.9gtb.com script on Champion store
Clean up stale SPF includes across all domains (BigCommerce, TrendMicro, Mandrill)
Add SRI hashes to all third-party scripts (Klaviyo, Gorgias, Intelligems)
Fix Harrison DNS: consolidate domains, add SPF/DMARC/MX records
Increase HSTS max-age to 1 year and submit for preload
Review and remove unnecessary third-party scripts on Black Pepper (flipbook, zooomyapps)
Add Secure flag to all cookies via Cloudflare transform rules
